AITCH confused me. I've never seen the H sound written down before, and I never even considered what it might look like in writing. A name and brand name being in the same area deepened my feeling of being lost there. I made educated guesses of a few letters and they turned out to be correct, but it was not an exercise I enjoyed on Tuesday.

I was about to ask why Tumbler solves to GLASS (it was my last word to fall in the grid) but I've just realized a tumbler is just a type of glass. I think this may be a Polish thing - our terminology regarding drinking glasses is much simpler: pretty much any glass is just... a glass (szklanka; the term for the *other* glass, as in the material glasses, window panes and bottles are made of is "szk≈Ço", which is also slang for drinking glasses, when used in relation to alcohol). An alcohol glass, and especially one with a stem, is called "kieliszek" (a diminutive of "kielich", from the German Kelch and Latin calix). But that's as far as it goes. If we want to specify a type of szklanka/kieliszek, we just say what it's for: szklanka do whisky, kieliszek do wina. There are no tumblers, drams, flutes, etc. So I may know what a tumbler is, but given my Polish neural pathways, it's not a word I recall naturally.

The demise of the in-flight magazine was driven in part by the advent of seat-back screens that can pitch ads directly into your eyeballs. 
But the trend was also financial, driven originally by American Airlines execs. They had a simple metric: how many kilos of in-flight magazines were they putting aboard their aircraft, and how much jet fuel did they spend to fly those dead trees around their routes? The "suits" decreed that the ad revenue had to be high enough to turn the mag from a loss to a profit center.
Similarly, American's polished-aluminum appearance was borne out of the calculation of the cost of flying so many kilos of paint around on the outside of their aircraft.

I had to look at the other comments to realize today's date.

April's Fools is called Prima Aprilis in Polish (Latin for April 1st; yes, in this case Polish uses a Latin expression, for some reason, not even as a loan word but as pure Latin). It used to be a huge thing here for decades, with major newspapers running fake stories on their front pages, and main news reports on TV following suit. My parents bought a whole stack of papers and magazines, and I would pore over them for hours trying to identify all the prank articles.

Also, obviously, whole families, including my parents and me, pulled pranks on one another. And while the pranks still remain a thing (my wife and I don't engage in them, mostly because we don't have kids and because I'm a predictable bore, but that's not typical of an average Polish household), the news outlets have been toning down their Prima Aprilis jokes for many years, and the phenomenon is almost dead these days.
@Andrzej   Why do you think it's dying out in Poland?  Is there a reason?

@Charlie 

I've wondered about this many times, but I don't have a concret answer. I do have a theory though.

The quality of Polish press - which wasn't bad in the 1990s, fresh from the rebirth of free speech in 1989 - has been dramatically decreasing over the past decade or two - these days it's all like clickbait: provocative titles accompanying dreadfully shallow articles abound. "You won't believe what so-and-so did!!!" a headline will scream, so you read on and... They didn't actually do anything. I'm not even exaggerating that much here. Even once prestigious newspapers, like "Gazeta Wyborcza" ("Election Newspaper", so called because it was established in 1989 by the democratic movement in the run-up to Poland's first semi-free elections in decades) have been reduced to tabloid levels. I find it very sad and dispiriting.

When all of the articles are sensationalist, their contents fake-newsy, what's the point of making stuff up specifically for Prima Aprilis?

@Andrzej 

That is not just a Polish thing.

@Warren 

Maybe not, and I'm not familiar with any details of the American example, but take the UK: The Guardian upholds the highest standards of journalism, and it does not try to complete with tabloids on sensationalism.

There is not a single such professional news outlet in this whole country!

I find myself not following any national news, because there simply is no good source for them. Everywhere there is only clickbait. The only foreign news that ever get covered in Poland are natural disasters, wars, autocrats' tirades and football (soccer, to you) matches. Economic developments? Scientific breakthroughs? Major cultural events? Nope. We will have none of that, thank you! In national news, gruesome car accidents get more coverage than important bills being introduced in Parliament.

I wish my parents had not insisited on giving me a good education - the world in general, and Poland specifically, would look much better through a fog of blissful ignorance and lack of understanding.

@Andrzej The decline in (democratized) literacy here, and elsewhere, has been well documented. e.g. https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/12/24/twilight-of-the-books It has led some sociologists to speculate that we are shifting back from a literate society to a secondary oral culture‚Äîfor a period, perhaps. ‚ÄúIn an oral culture, clich√© and stereotype are valued, as accumulations of wisdom, and analysis is frowned upon, for putting those accumulations at risk‚Ä¶ Opponents in struggle are more memorable than calm and abstract investigations, so bards revel in name-calling and in ‚Äòenthusiastic description of physical violence.‚Äô‚Äù Your longings at the end of your post reflect the primal urge behind this shift, I think. Confirmation bias and conspiracy theories, apparently, are more comforting than fact-based critical thinking and changing one‚Äôs mind as one learns. (https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/26/opinion/kennedy-epstein-conspiracy.html?unlocked_article_code=1.8U4.1yt7.d9WQ9zJqDMl8&smid=url-share) Modern media outlets are just following the money. Most of the ones that don‚Äôt, fail. The ones left that try to live up to the highest standards you cite are unicorns, soon to be fables we tell to our grandchildren. Witness the Washington Post. In 2007, Mr. Crain concluded his New Yorker essay with, ‚ÄúSuch a habit [reading] might be quite dangerous for a democracy to lose.‚Äù Indeed.
